Graphical Abstract The Ni/Atta catalysts with the different pores activated by KOH showed the distinct resistivity towards coke formation in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol and affected the type of the reaction intermediates formed. Attapulgite clay (Atta), a natural mineral, can be used as support of various catalysts. Nevertheless, the limited surface affects its applications. In this study, the activation of Atta with KOH to enhance surface area was developed and supported nickel catalysts were evaluated in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol. The results showed that the activation by KOH created abundant micropores in Atta via the solid phase reaction between KOH and SiO2 and Al2O3. The activation also enhanced reduction degree of nickel oxide, interaction between nickel and Atta, dispersion of nickel species and alkalinity of the catalyst, rendering the superior catalytic activity in steam reforming of either acetic acid or guaiacol. The in-situ Diffused Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy characterization of the steam reforming reaction indicated that the activation facilitated absorption of *OH and *CO2 species on catalyst for gasifying the coke precursors such as the ones containing C = O, enhancing resistivity of the catalyst towards coking. In addition, owing to the different molecular structures, steam reforming of acetic acid and guaiacol over the catalyst encountered the different steric hindrance, different tendencies towards coking and different properties of coke. Specially, the catalyst showed varied sensitivity towards coking in steam reforming reaction. Keywords Steam reforming Attapulgite KOH activation Ni/Attapulgite Coke formation 1 Introduction Attapulgite clay (Atta) is a hydrated aluminum-magnesium silicate with typically a slatted or fibrous morphology [1]. Atta is characterized by a porous crystalline structure that includes a tetrahedral layer chained together along a longitudinal sideline [2]. Due to its unique structure, natural Atta has been widely used as adsorbents, coatings, binders, catalysts and catalyst supports [3,4]. However, depending on the origin and composition, some Atta has limited specific surface area, which could significantly affect the dispersion of the active metal species when Atta is used as the supporting material [5,6]. For example, in the Ni/Atta catalyst, the nickel dispersion on the surface of Atta is governed by the characteristics of the pores in Atta. Further to this, when Ni/Atta catalyst is used for catalyzing the conversion of the reactants with a certain molecular size [7,8], the mass transfer limitation of the reactants and the reaction intermediates could also be an important factor impacting the reaction kinetics and the performances of the catalyst [9–12]. Tailoring the pore structure of Atta is of importance for enhancing the dispersion of active metal species and for minimizing the mass transfer limitations of reactants/reaction intermediates. It has been known that the treatment of silica support with alkaline such as NaOH or KOH could restructure the pores in the silica materials such as SBA-15 and KIT-6 [13–17]. This is because NaOH or KOH could react with SiO2, destroying the crystallinities of SiO2 and forming Na2SiO3 or K2SiO3 that are water soluble [18]. Via this, the original pores in silica materials could be enlarged and additional pores are created. SiO2 is an important fraction in Atta [4]. Thus, the specific surface area and porous structure of Atta could possibly be modified via the treatment with alkaline. In this study, the thermal treatment of Atta with varied content of KOH was conducted to enhance its specific surface area. The activated Atta were used as the carrier for nickel-based catalysts. The results showed that the activation of the Atta with alkaline could significantly increase the specific surface area, which enhanced the nickel dispersion, interaction of nickel with Atta and the strength/abundance of the basic sites of the catalysts. Steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol was selected as the model reactions to evaluate the catalytic performance of the Ni/Atta catalysts. The rationale for chosen acetic acid or guaiacol as the model molecule is due to that both acetic acid and guaiacol are important compounds in the bio-oil generated from pyrolysis biomass [19,20]. They respectively represent the carboxylic acids and phenolics in bio-oil [21,22]. Understanding the reaction behaviors of them provides the valuable information for steam reforming of whole bio-oil. More importantly, guaiacol and acetic acid have distinct molecular size, and they would encounter the distinct mass transfer limitations or steric hindrance during the steam reforming over the Ni/Atta catalysts with the varied porous structures. The catalytic results showed that the Ni/Atta catalysts with the different pores showed the distinct resistivity towards coke formation in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol and affected the type of the reaction intermediates formed. More importantly, the results demonstrated that the deactivation of the catalysts were closely related to the properties of the coke formed but rather than the amount of the coke formed. The amount/properties of the coke deposit are related to both the nature of the reactant and the varied porous structures of Atta. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals All the chemicals used in this study were analytical grade. The solvent used was double distilled water. Guaiacol and acetic acid were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. The other chemicals including nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O) and potassium hydroxide (KOH) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of the catalysts The attapulgite (moisture content: 3-8%; PH value: 7.5-9.8) carrier was purchased from Anhui MingmeiMin Chem Co., Ltd. Before the impregnation of nickel species, the Atta carrier was firstly activated by varied content of KOH. The typical procedure for the activation is briefly shown below. Atta and potassium hydroxide with the varied mass ratio (1 : 1 or 2 : 1) were mechanically mixed and thoroughly ground. After that, the mixed sample was calcined in a muffle furnace at 700 °C with the ramping rate of 20 °C/min for 2 h and the calcined samples were washed with double distilled water thoroughly to remove the soluble salts, which was then dried for the impregnation of nickel species. The impregnation of nickel species to the activated Atta (25 wt% to Atta) was performed by using an equivalent wetness impregnation method. The impregnated sample was firstly dried at room temperature (ca. 25 °C) and was then calcined in a muffle furnace at 600 °C (ramping rate: 20 °C/min) for 2 h. 2.3 Catalytic test Steam reforming reactions were performed in a fixed-bed continuous flow reactor. The Ni/Atta catalysts were firstly reduced at 600 °C for 1 h in hydrogen atmosphere (60 mL/min) and the reaction temperature was then set to the required reaction temperature. Water and the reactant were fed into the reactor and maintained at each investigated temperature for 30 min for collecting the liquid and gaseous products for further analysis. Steam reforming of acetic acid was conducted under the specific conditions (S/C = 5; LHSV =10.4 h-1; T = 300, 400, 500, 600 and 700 °C), while the steam reforming of guaiacol was performed under the followed conditions (S/C = 5; LHSV =21.1 h-1; T = 300, 400, 500, 600, 700 and 800 °C) for measuring the activity of the catalysts. The specific reaction conditions for the steam reforming of the organics with the prolonged reaction time were specified in the text. Furthermore, the formulas for the definition of the reaction parameters and calculation of the conversion/yields can be found in our previous study [23]. Conversion of guaiacol/acetic acid = ((Amount of guaiacol/acetic acid fed – Amount of guaiacol/acetic acid unconverted) / Amount of guaiacol/acetic acid fed) × 100%. Yield of CO2/CO/CH4 (in steam reforming of guaiacol) = (Moles of CO2/CO/CH4 produced / 7 × Moles of guaiacol fed) × 100%. Yield of CO2/CO/CH4 (in steam reforming of acetic acid) = (Moles of CO2/CO/CH4 produced / 2 × Moles of acetic acid fed) × 100%. Yield of H2 = (Moles of H2 produced / Theoretical moles of H2 from the guaiacol/acetic acid fed) × 100%. 2.4 Catalysts characterizations The textural structure (specific surface area, mean pore radius and pore volume) of the nickel-based catalysts was analyzed with the Biaode SSA–6000 instrument and calculated by using the BET (Brunauer-Emmett-Teller) and BJH (Barrett-Joyner-Halenda) formulas. The crystalline structure of the catalysts was evaluated by the X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectrometer (Rigaku Ultima IV instrument). The reduction behaviors of NiO were analyzed with H2-Temperature Programmed Reduction (H2-TPR; Vodo VDSorb-91x instrument), and the reduction degree of NiO was calculated by using an external standard method. The basic sites on the catalysts after activation were analyzed by the CO2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (CO2-TPD; PCA-1200 instrument) characterization. The metal dispersion of nickel particles was investigated with the H2-Temperature Programmed Desorption (H2-TPD; Vodo VDSorb-91x instrument) characterization. In addition, the intermediates in the steam reforming of the organics were analyzed by the in-situ Diffused Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (DRIFTS) characterization with the Nicolet IS 50 instrument. After steam reforming of the organics with the prolonged reaction time, the spent catalysts were analyzed by a series of characterizations. The amount of coke formed on the spent catalysts was analyzed by Thermogravimetric (TG) in air atmosphere, which was conducted in TG8121 Rigaku instrument. The stability of coke formed on the spent catalysts was investigated by TG in nitrogen atmosphere. In addition, the oxidation temperature of coke was evaluated by Temperature Programmed oxidation (TPO; PCA-1200 instrument) characterization. The graphitization of coke and the functional groups formed of the coke on the spent catalysts was analyzed by the Raman (Horiba LabRam HR Evolution instrument) and Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FT-IR; Nicolet iS50 instrument) characterization, respectively. The morphology of the coke on the spent catalysts was analyzed by the Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) characterization in JEOL2010PLUS instrument. The liquid products formed in the steam reforming reaction were analyzed by Gas Chromatography and Mass Spectrometry (GC-MS; Shimadzu GC-MS-QP 2020 instrument). Furthermore, the polymers formed in the steam reforming reaction were characterized by the fluorescence spectrometer (Shimadzu, RF-6000) characterization. The specific conditions for the above characterizations could be found in our previous study [23]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Physicochemical properties of the catalysts 3.1.1 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of the calcined and reduced nickel-based catalysts were shown in Fig. 1 a and b, respectively. Without activation, the diffraction peaks of Ni/Atta catalysts were complicated, which mainly corresponded to the crystal phases of silica and alumina phase in the original Atta carrier. After KOH activation, the diffraction peaks of SiO2 (JCPDS 99-0088) and Al2O3 (JCPDS 78-2426) were basically disappeared, indicating that the KOH activation could restructure the crystal phase composition of the Atta carrier. KOH obviously reacted with SiO2 to form the K2SiO3, breaking down the crystal lattices of silica. Nevertheless, KOH could also react with alumina, reducing its crystallinity in Atta. In addition to the diffraction of carrier, the diffraction peaks at 2θ = 37.3°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4° and 79.4° could be assigned to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0), (2 2 0), (3 1 1) and (2 2 2) facets of the cubic phase of nickel oxide (JCPDS 75-0269). The particle size of NiO was calculated by using Debye-Scherrer formula, and the results (Table 1 ) showed that the NiO particle size decreased with increase the KOH content for the activation, indicating that the activated Atta support could enhance the metal dispersion of NiO or inhibit the agglomeration of NiO during the calcination process. After the reduction process, the diffraction peaks of Atta carrier were not significantly changed in the fresh Ni/Atta catalyst. The reduction process did not affect the restructure of the phase composition of the Atta carrier. The nickel oxide species were totally reduced to the species of metallic nickel (JCPDS 87-0712) after the reduction, with the diffraction peaks located at 2θ of 44.5°, 51.8° and 76.4°, which could be assigned to the (1 1 1), (2 0 0) and (2 2 0) planes. However, the diffraction peaks for nickel oxide were still visible, illustrating that the nickel oxide species were not totally reduced to the metallic nickel species. The unreduced nickel oxide particles were probably caused by strong interaction between the nickel oxide and the carrier, which will be investigated later via the H2-TPR characterization. The nickel particle size was further calculated and shown in Table 1. The results again confirmed that the activation of Atta could promote the metal dispersion of nickel species. The activation of Atta with KOH might result in the change of the porous structure of Atta, which was further investigated by the BET characterizations. 3.1.2 Surface area and pore structure analysis The specific surface area and pore structures of Atta and Ni/Atta catalysts were summarized in Fig. 2 and Table 1. For the Atta carrier before the activation, it had mainly the mesopores with the mean pore radius of 9.4 nm. After the activation with KOH, the mean pore radius was significantly decreased but the specific surface area was enhanced substantially. Interestingly, the pore volume of the Atta carrier activated with KOH with the mass ratio of 1:1 for the treatment was same as that of un-activated Atta. Nevertheless, the specific surface area increased significantly while the mean pore radius was decreased. For the activation of Atta with more KOH (2 : 1 for the mass ratio), the pore volume increased, but not in proportion to the increase of the specific surface area. Obviously, the activation with KOH mainly created the micropores in Atta, which did not induce the significant change of the pore volume. After the impregnation of 25 wt% Ni onto the Atta carrier, the pore volume and the specific surface area for all the catalysts decreased substantially. Evidently, nickel species filled or partially filled the micropores and mesopores after loading to Atta. The deposition of nickel species inside the inner pores of the Atta might affect its access to the reactants, which will be discussed later. The isothermal curves (Fig. 2a and c) showed that all the catalysts showed the IV type Langmuir adsorption-desorption isotherm. For Atta carrier, the area of isothermal curves increased with the increasing KOH ratio, illustrating that the more pores were formed as the KOH activation ratio increased. In addition, for Ni/Atta catalysts, the area of isothermal curves had the opposite trend. For fresh Ni/Atta catalyst, the more mesopores were mainly generated from the accumulation of nickel particles. The varied pore structure of Atta or the activated Atta might affect the interaction of nickel species with Atta, which was further investigated with the TPR characterizations. 3.1.3 TPR analysis The results for the TPR characterization were shown in Fig. 3 a and b. The reduction peaks were divided into three regions, located at ca. 510 °C, 590 °C and 760 °C, respectively, which was caused by the varied degree of interaction of nickel oxide with the Atta carrier [24,25]. After the activation of the Atta with KOH, the reduction peaks of NiO shifted remarkably to the higher temperature. Obviously, the portion of the nickel species strongly interacted with Atta carrier increased with the activation of the Atta. The activation of Atta changed the distribution of the atoms on the surface status of Atta, which thus further changed the interaction of nickel species with Atta. Further to this, the activation of Atta created the small pores, while nickel species filled the small pores during the impregnation. This would create the mass transfer limitations during the reduction and thus also contributed to the upwards shift of the reduction temperature. Porous carrier could provide more sites for the interaction with the nickel particles. The reduction degree of nickel oxide was also calculated as shown in Fig. 3b. The results showed that the strong interaction of the nickel species with the activated Atta did not decrease the reduction degree of nickel oxide. On the contrary, the reduction degree in the un-activated Atta was much lower. Possibly, the bigger particle size of nickel oxide in the nickel supported on the un-activated Atta made the reduction of the nickel oxide inner the particles more difficult, leading to the lower reduction degree. The different reduction degree and the particle size of nickel species would affect the dispersion of nickel on the Atta carrier, which was further investigated with the H2-TPD characterization. 3.1.4 H2-TPD analysis The results of the H2-TPD analysis were shown in Fig. 3c and d. The desorption peaks of hydrogen in the samples mainly located at 50-250 °C, 250-550 °C and 550-800 °C, respectively. After the activation of Atta with KOH, the desorption peak of hydrogen in the 1:1 Ni/Atta and 2:1 Ni/Atta catalysts were more intensified at the medium to high temperature region. Obviously, after the KOH activation, the nickel sites on surface of the catalysts showed a stronger interaction with hydrogen. During the steam reforming of the organics, hydrogen is the targeting products [26,27]. Its formation involves the absorption on surface of nickel, their integration to H2 and the desorption of H2 to form gaseous H2 [28]. Thus, the varied extent of absorption of hydrogen on surface of the catalyst might also affect the catalytic reactions. The nickel dispersion as well as the particle size of metallic nickel (calculated from the XRD results) is shown in Fig. 3d. Clearly, the 2:1 Ni/Atta or the 1:1 Ni/Atta catalyst with the smaller particle size of nickel possessed the higher dispersion of metallic nickel. This was the expected results as the smaller size of nickel had the bigger exposed outer area. Further to this, the higher reduction degree of the 2:1 Ni/Atta or the 1:1 Ni/Atta catalyst (Fig. 3b) also contributed to the higher dispersion of metallic nickel as more metallic nickel were available. In addition to the nickel dispersion, the effects of KOH activation on the alkalinity of the catalyst were also explored with CO2-TPD characterization. 3.1.5 CO2–TPD characterization The distribution of the basic sites on the Atta carrier and nickel-based catalysts after the KOH activation were investigate with CO2-TPD characterization and the results were shown in Fig. 4 . The desorption of CO2 at the varied temperature related to the strength of the basic sites over the catalysts. The distribution of the basic sites could be divided into three regions according to the desorption temperature of CO2: weak basic sites (T < 180 °C), medium basic sites (from 180 °C to 480 °C) and strong basic sites (T > 480 °C) [29,30]. For Atta carrier, the activation with KOH introduced additional basic sites on the surface of carrier, especially for medium and strong basic sites (Fig. 4a and b). After the impregnation of nickel species, the total abundance of the basic sites for all the catalysts further increased when compared with the activated Atta carrier, indicating that the presence of nickel species also increased the abundance of basic sites. In addition, the medium basic sites over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalysts were significantly increased via the activation of Atta with KOH. The presence of the basic sites could enhance the absorption of CO2 and steam, which was beneficial for gasifying the precursors of the coke formed on the surface of catalyst [31,32]. The above characterization showed that the activation of Atta with KOH could clearly impact the porous structure of the carrier, the particle sizes, the reduction degree, the dispersion of nickel species and the alkalinity on surface of the catalysts. This might further affect the activity of the catalyst, the reaction intermediates formed, and the resistivity of the catalyst towards coke formation in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol, which was further investigated. 3.2 Catalytic performances 3.2.1 Steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol The conversion of acetic acid and yield of main products during the steam reforming of acetic acid over the nickel-based catalysts were shown in Fig. 5 . In terms of the yield of hydrogen, the 1:1 Ni/Atta and 2:1 Ni/Atta catalysts showed some improvement for the conversion of acetic acid and the reaction intermediates into hydrogen at high temperature. The results for steam reforming of guaiacol, a molecule with bigger size, were shown in Fig. 6 . Steam reforming of guaiacol was more difficult when compared with that of acetic acid, due to the presence of the benzene skeleton that was more difficult to break. As shown in Fig. 6, negligible amount of hydrogen was formed at the reaction temperature below 500 °C. The activation of the Atta support with KOH or not showed more significant influence on the activity of the catalyst for catalyzing the conversion of guaiacol via steam reforming. As discussed above, the Atta support had abundant micropores, and guaiacol with a bigger molecule sizes would be more sensitive towards the steric hindrances. More exposed metallic nickel and more pores in the 1:1 Ni/Atta and 2:1 Ni/Atta catalysts could clearly enhance the conversion of guaiacol via steam reforming. In addition, the isomerization or polymerisation of guaiacol at the lower reaction temperature were responsible for the conversion of guaiacol at the low temperature regions, as characterized with GC-MS (Fig. S1) and UV fluorescence (Fig. S2). The reactivity of acetic acid or guaiacol during the steam reforming relates to the formation of the organic reaction intermediates, which were further characterized with the in-situ DRIFTS characterization. 3.2.2 In-situ DRIFTS characterization of the reaction intermediates The results for the formation of the reaction intermediates characterized with in-situ DRIFTS characterization in the steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol were shown in Figs. 7 and 8 , respectively. For steam reforming of acetic acid (Fig. 7), the functional groups of the reaction intermediates formed on the surface of catalysts included hydroxyl group (3740 cm-1), C-H functionalities (2960 cm-1), CO2 (2370 and 2300 cm-1), C = O functionalities (1735 cm-1), C = C functionalities (1570 and 1430 cm-1), C-O functionalities (1580 and 1150 cm-1) and C-H functionalities (1050 and 860 cm-1). Comparing the results in Fig. 7a and b, it was found that relative intensity of the hydroxyl group (with the absorption of 3450 cm-1 as the base) was more significant over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst than over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst with the un-activated support. The characterization for the CO2-adsorption indicated that the alkalinity of the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was much higher than that over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst (Fig. 7). The higher alkalinity could clearly enhance the absorption of hydroxyl group, presence of which is essential for facilitating the elimination of coke formation via gasifying the precursors of coke [33]. As for the absorption of C = O functionalities, the intensity of the peak was more significant over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst than over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. The reaction intermediates bearing the carbonyl functionality could potentially involve in the polymerisation reactions such as via Aldol condensation, which could be the precursors for coke formation. The more available metallic nickel species (the higher nickel dispersion) in the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst could clearly eliminate the accumulation of the intermediates containing the carbonyl functionality. This could also be possibly related to the abundant hydroxyl group that could aid the gasification of these reaction intermediates. In addition, it was interesting to find that although the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst had a higher alkalinity and showed a higher capability to absorb CO2, as characterized with the CO2-TPD method (Fig. 4), the absorption peak for CO2 in the in situ DRIFTS experiments was much lower than that over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. Probably, the highly dispersed metallic nickel sites aided the gasification of the carbonaceous reaction intermediates with CO2, resulting in little CO2 accumulation on surface of the catalyst. The absorption of other reaction intermediates did not differ significantly between the catalysts. Similar distribution of the functionalities of the reaction intermediates in steam reforming of guaiacol was observed (Fig. 8). The relative absorption intensity of hydroxyl group over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was more significant than over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. Besides, the evident absorption of C = O over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was also more significant than that over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. The higher dispersion of nickel and the alkalinity of the catalyst were of importance for effective elimination of the reaction intermediates containing the carbonyl functionalities. The reaction intermediates formed closely related to the coking reactions in the steam reforming, which were further investigated in steam reforming of acetic acid and guaiacol with the prolonged reaction time. 3.2.3 Steam reforming versus the prolonged reaction time The steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol versus the prolonged reaction time was investigated and the results were shown in Fig. 9 . For steam reforming of acetic acid, both the catalysts did not show the sign of deactivation under the experimental conditions employed. However, in steam reforming of guaiacol, the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst deactivated quickly with the prolonged reaction time. In comparison, the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was much stable under the same reaction conditions. In addition, the catalytic performance of 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was also much higher than 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. The liquid products analysis showed that phenol was the main organic by-product formed in steam reforming of guaiacol (Fig. S3). In addition, the polymerization of guaiacol took place to a significant extent over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst (Fig. S4), while over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst the polymerization could be effectively suppressed. Coking is one of the main reasons for the deactivation of the catalysts in steam reforming reactions [34,35]. The formation of coke on outer surface and inner surface of the catalyst could totally block the pores of the catalyst, preventing the access of the metal sites inside the pores for the access to reactants [36]. Besides, the pores could also be partially blocked. The metal sites inside the pores might still be accessible but certainly with some steric hindrance. In this scenario, the molecule size matters. Acetic acid has a smaller molecular size than guaiacol, and thus might be less sensitive towards coke formation. The formation of coke in steam reforming of acetic acid and in that of guaiacol was further investigated. 3.2.4 Characterization of the coke formed over the spent catalysts The crystalline structure of the spent catalysts after the steam reforming versus the prolonged reaction time was evaluated by XRD characterization and shown in Fig. 10 a. The crystalline structure of Atta carrier did not change much compared with the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts, while the crystal phase of coke species was clearly observed in the spent catalysts after steam reforming of acetic acid versus the prolonged reaction time. Probably, the coke formed on the spent catalysts in steam reforming of acetic acid was more significant than that over the catalysts in steam reforming of guaiacol. In addition, the nickel particle size was calculated with Debye-Scherrer formula and the results were shown in Table S1. The particle size of metallic nickel in the spent catalysts in acetic acid steam reforming versus prolonged the reaction time was significantly smaller than that in the catalysts after reduction. This interesting phenomenon showed that the nickel particles on the catalysts appear to be re-dispersed during the steam reforming reaction. The nickel particle size (12.0 nm) of the catalysts after KOH activation and the catalytic test was smaller than that in the fresh catalysts (13.7 nm), illustrating that the developed pore structure plays a positive role in the re-dispersion of nickel particles. Furthermore, the particle size of the catalysts after guaiacol steam reforming versus prolonged reaction time was not remarkably changed, while the catalytic activity decreased remarkably. Sintering of metallic nickel was thus not the main reason for the deactivation of the catalyst in steam reforming of guaiacol while the coke formation probably was the reason, which was further investigated with TG and TPO characterizations. The results for the TG-air and the TPO characterizations were shown in Fig. 10b, c and d, respectively. The amount of coke formed on the catalysts after acetic acid steam reforming was significant. Nevertheless, after the activation of Atta with KOH, the amount of coke over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was much lower than that over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. The higher nickel dispersion and the higher alkalinity of the catalyst with the activated Atta were clearly favorable for gasifying the precursors of coke formation. This was more evident in steam reforming of guaiacol. As shown in Fig. 10b, the TG curve for the spent 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst obtained in steam reforming of guaiacol even increased a little bit in the air flow. During the oxidation of coke on the surface of the catalyst, the oxidation of the carbonaceous species resulted in the weight decrease while the oxidation of metallic nickel resulted in the weight gain. Clearly, the weight gain for the spent 2:1 Ni/Atta herein in the TG characterization was due to the oxidization of nickel particles, while coke formed during the steam reforming of guaiacol over this catalyst was insignificant. The TPO results (Fig. 10d) also showed that, for acetic acid steam reforming, the oxidization peak for the coke over the KOH activated catalyst was much higher (ca. 715 °C), which further indicated that the KOH activation affect the stability of the coke formed. For guaiacol steam reforming, the oxidization peak of 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was significantly lower than that over the fresh catalyst, indicating that the coke formed on the activated catalyst was much lower and more stable, which was consistent with the stability of the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. The above characterizations showed that there was a significant difference for the coke formed on the catalyst, which was further investigated by TG-N2, FT-IR and Raman characterizations. The thermal stability of the coke formed in the steam reforming reactions was also evaluated by the TG/DTG test in N2 atmosphere (Fig. 10e and f). The percentage of vaporized coke in acetic acid steam reforming was higher over the 0:1 Ni/Atta than over the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst. It has been reported that the coke with the higher thermal stability was the catalytic type of coke in the form of such as carbon nanotubes [37]. This type of coke does not remarkably lead to the deactivation of the catalyst, as the amorphous coke does [37,38]. For steam reforming of guaiacol, the percentage for the weight loss for the spent catalyst was 21.3%, indicating that a significant portion of the coke was the polymeric coke with the lower thermal stability. For the spent 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst in steam reforming of guaiacol, there was slight weight loss, which was in line with the results in Fig. 10b, where the coke formed over this catalyst was insignificant. In addition, the DTG results showed that the weight loss for the coke formed from steam reforming of acetic acid started at ca. 500 °C while that in steam reforming of guaiacol started at ca. 600 °C. The benzene ring with the conjugated π-bond structure resulted in the coke with the higher thermal stability. The functional groups of the coke species over the spent catalysts were analyzed with FT-IR and the results were shown in Fig. 11 a. The functional groups like -OH, C-H, C = O, C = C and aliphatic C-O-C were observed in all the spent catalysts. The abundance of C-O-C was remarkably higher in the spent catalysts after guaiacol steam reforming, which probably attributed to the C-O-C structures formed from the polymerization of guaiacol. The C = O functional groups was also observed in the spent catalysts (Fig. 11b). Some carbonaceous species bearing the carbonyl functionality could not be effectively gasified and were retained in the coke formed. In addition, the aliphatic C-H in alkanes was also observed in the coke species. The Raman results of the spent catalyst were shown in Fig. 11c. The D band corresponds to the plane vibration of sp2-bonded carbon structures with structural defects, and G-band corresponds to the plane vibration of sp2-bonded graphite-like structures [39,40]. The results showed that the ratio of D to G bands of the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalysts was much lower than 0:1 Ni/Atta catalysts, especially for the catalyst after guaiacol steam reforming, indicating that the coke formed on the activated catalysts were much stable and the graphitization of the activated catalysts were much higher [39,40], which was in line with the above characterizations. The morphology of spent catalysts was characterized by the TEM characterization and the results were shown in Fig. 12 . In general, in the spent catalysts, the coke was in the mixture of amorphous form and carbon nanotube form. The TEM image obtained showed that the amorphous coke formed was more dominant over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst, while the carbon nanotube was the main form of coke formed on the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst in steam reforming of acetic acid. In addition, the carbon nanotubes formed on surface of the catalyst had the varied diameters, which corresponded to the dispersion of metallic nickel species with the varied particle sizes. For the spent catalyst in the steam reforming of guaiacol, the carbon nanotube with the bamboo-like structure was observed (Fig. 13 ). The formation of this type of unique structure was related to the special reaction intermediates formed during the steam reforming of guaiacol and also the surface properties of the catalyst. In comparison, over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst such structure was not observed. The alkalinity or other properties of the 2:1 Ni/Atta catalyst was probably responsible for the formation of such structure. The appearance of the coke formed over the 0:1 Ni/Atta catalyst in steam reforming of guaiacol was in the form of amorphous coke with some in the form of carbon nanofiber. The formation of the amorphous coke was the main reason for the rapid deactivation of the catalyst in steam reforming of guaiacol. 4 Conclusions To sum up, the impacts of the activation of Atta with KOH on the catalytic behaviors of Ni/Atta catalyst in steam reforming of acetic acid and guaiacol were investigated. The results showed that KOH could react with both the SiO2 and Al2O3 components in Atta, which created abundant micropores in Atta and significantly increased the surface area of Atta and the dispersion of nickel species via reducing the particle size of nickel. The activation of the Atta with KOH also enhanced the interaction between nickel and the Atta carrier, which suppressed the agglomeration of nickel. Furthermore, the KOH activation also enhanced the reduction degree of nickel oxide and introduced abundant basic sites with medium and strong strength. The higher dispersion of metallic nickel and alkalinity of the KOH activated Ni/Atta catalysts contributed to their superior catalytic activity in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol. The in-situ DRIFTS characterization of steam reforming reactions showed that the higher alkalinity could enhance the absorption of hydroxyl group and CO2 intermediates on surface of the catalyst for gasifying the precursors for coke formation such as the intermediates containing the carbonyl functionality. This effectively enhanced the resistivity of the catalyst towards coke formation, either in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol. Specially, the coke formed over the catalyst with KOH activation was negligible while was remarkable over the catalyst without the activation. Acetic acid and guaiacol also showed the distinct reaction behaviors in the steam reforming reactions due to their distinct molecular structural configuration. The amount of coke formed over the catalysts in steam reforming of acetic acid was significant while was much less in steam reforming of guaiacol over the un-activated Ni/Atta catalyst. However, the catalyst deactivated in steam reforming of guaiacol while was not in steam reforming of acetic acid. The formation of coke could totally or partially block the pores, which affected the access of the metal sites to reactants or created the steric hindrance for accessing the metal sites. Acetic acid has a smaller molecular size than guaiacol, and would encounter lower steric hindrance and thus was less sensitive towards coke formation. In addition, over the un-activated catalyst, the coke formed was mainly in the amorphous form with the lower thermal stability while over the KOH activated catalyst the carbon nanotube form coke was dominant in steam reforming of acetic acid. In steam reforming of guaiacol, the coke with the bamboo-like structure was observed, which was related to the nature of guaiacol and the reaction intermediates. The results herein demonstrated that the activation of Atta with KOH significantly tailored the physiochemical properties of the Ni/Atta, the catalytic activity, stability resistivity towards coke formation and coke properties. Other methods for activation of Atta also deserve further attention for tailing the catalytic behaviors of the Atta-based catalyst in heterogeneous reactions. coredata.dc:description: Attapulgite clay (Atta), a natural mineral, can be used as support of various catalysts. Nevertheless, the limited surface affects its applications. In this study, the activation of Atta with KOH to enhance surface area was developed and supported nickel catalysts were evaluated in steam reforming of acetic acid or guaiacol. The results showed that the activation by KOH created abundant micropores in Atta via the solid phase reaction between KOH and SiO2 and Al2O3. The activation also enhanced reduction degree of nickel oxide, interaction between nickel and Atta, dispersion of nickel species and alkalinity of the catalyst, rendering the superior catalytic activity in steam reforming of either acetic acid or guaiacol. The in-situ Diffused Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy characterization of the steam reforming reaction indicated that the activation facilitated absorption of *OH and *CO2 species on catalyst for gasifying the coke precursors such as the ones containing C = O, enhancing resistivity of the catalyst towards coking. In addition, owing to the different molecular structures, steam reforming of acetic acid and guaiacol over the catalyst encountered the different steric hindrance, different tendencies towards coking and different properties of coke. Specially, the catalyst showed varied sensitivity towards coking in steam reforming reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Steam reforming of acetic acid and guaiacol over Ni/Attapulgite catalyst: Tailoring pore structure of the catalyst with KOH activation for enhancing the resistivity towards coking
